queries.company_overview:
What it does: Figma, Inc. provides a browser-based collaborative design and product development platform that enables teams to ideate, design, prototype, hand off to developers, and publish assets, with AI-enhanced workflows. 
Main business units / segments:
- Figma Design (collaborative UI/UX design and prototyping)
- FigJam (whiteboarding and ideation)
- Dev Mode and developer tools
- Slides (presentations)
- AI/workflow products: Make, Draw, Sites, Buzz
High-level financials: FY2024 revenue $749.0M; FY2024 net loss $732.1M (USD). Market capitalization $22.47B as of 2025-11-05.
Competitive positioning: Figma competes with Adobe (creative/product design), Sketch, and Canva in design, and with Miro and Lucid in whiteboarding/collaboration. Its browser-native, multiplayer architecture, enterprise adoption, and expanding suite across design, ideation, and developer workflows provide differentiation versus desktop-first incumbents. The terminated Adobe transaction underscored Figma’s strategic relevance in creative and product design markets.
Recent major news:
- 2025-10-15 Figma set Q3 2025 results for 2025-11-05; IPO lock-up termination on 2025-11-07
- 2025-10-06 OpenAI highlighted Figma’s ChatGPT integration; shares rallied on integration showcase
- 2025-09-03 Q2 2025 revenue $249.6M (+41% YoY); launched Make, Draw, Sites, Buzz; acquired Modyfi and Payload; NDR 129%
- 2025-08-12 Global settlement with Motiff; Motiff to cease selling Editor Tool outside mainland China
- 2025-07-30 Priced IPO at $33/share; began NYSE trading as FIG on 2025-07-31

What specific pricing or packaging chang.query: What specific pricing or packaging changes will Figma announce for Q4 2025 enterprise plans?
What specific pricing or packaging chang.answer: There are no new Q4 2025–specific announcements for Enterprise pricing or packaging beyond the March 11, 2025 overhaul. Enterprise remains on the multi‑product seat model—Full $90, Dev $35, Collab $5 per user/month (annual billing only)—with FigJam and Figma Slides included in all paid seats and updated admin approval/proration. The new prices take effect at each customer’s first renewal on or after March 11, 2025, which for many Enterprise accounts falls in Q4 2025.

search_results.title: Updates to Figma’s pricing, seats, and billing experience
search_results.snippet: Figma outlines its March 11, 2025 pricing and billing update: higher Figma Design prices, new multi-product seats, FigJam and Slides included with all paid seats, and admin approval with prorated billing; new pricing starts at a customer’s first renewal on/after March 11, 2025 (e.g., an annual plan renewing on October 15, 2025 switches then), with no separate Q4 2025 Enterprise-specific change noted.

search_results.title: Pricing
search_results.snippet: The current Enterprise tier shows multi-product seat pricing billed annually: Collab $5, Dev $35, Full $90 per user/month, with access spanning Figma Design, Dev Mode, FigJam, Slides, and other products; the page reflects the packaging model in effect now, not a new Q4 2025-specific announcement.

search_results.title: Updates to our pricing, seats, and billing experience | Figma Blog
search_results.snippet: Figma’s official announcement details the 2025 changes: price increases for Design, a shift to Full/Dev/Collab multi-product seats, upfront admin seat-approval with temporary access and proration, and a roadmap to Connected Projects later in 2025; it does not introduce a distinct Q4 2025 Enterprise pricing/packaging change.

What was Figma's Q3 2025 net dollar rete.query: What was Figma's Q3 2025 net dollar retention rate and drivers by cohort?
What was Figma's Q3 2025 net dollar rete.answer: As of the Q3 FY2025 earnings date, Figma had not yet disclosed a Q3 2025 net dollar retention (NDR) figure. The most recent disclosed NDR prior to Q3 was 129% in Q2 FY2025, measured for the cohort of paid customers with >$10K ARR. Management said this was driven primarily by seat expansion within existing customers and by renewals under the company’s new pricing and packaging model; note Figma calculates NDR only on the >$10K ARR customer cohort.

search_results.snippet: In its Q2 FY2025 press release, Figma reported a 129% Net Dollar Retention Rate for paid customers with >$10,000 ARR and described its NDR methodology as being calculated only on that >$10K ARR cohort, reflecting expansion, contraction, and churn.

search_results.snippet: On the Q2 FY2025 call, management stated NDR was 129% for >$10K ARR customers and said it was primarily driven by seat expansion within existing accounts and renewals tied to the new pricing and packaging model—clarifying the drivers for that high-value cohort.

When will Figma's ChatGPT Apps SDK integ.query: When will Figma's ChatGPT Apps SDK integration be generally available and what capabilities included?
When will Figma's ChatGPT Apps SDK integ.answer: Figma’s ChatGPT integration built on the Apps SDK is available now (announced Oct 6, 2025) to all logged‑in ChatGPT users outside the EU across Free, Go, Plus and Pro, with EU availability coming soon. It lets ChatGPT recommend and create FigJam diagrams directly in the chat—such as flowcharts, sequence and state diagrams, and Gantt charts—guided by conversation or uploaded files, and you can open them in FigJam to edit and collaborate. The Apps SDK itself is in developer preview, with broader submissions and support for Business, Enterprise and Edu planned later this year.

search_results.title: Apps in ChatGPT and the Apps SDK | OpenAI Help Center
search_results.snippet: OpenAI states that apps in ChatGPT are available today to all logged‑in users outside the EU on Free, Go, Plus and Pro plans, with EU availability coming soon. The initial partners—Booking.com, Canva, Coursera, Expedia, Spotify, Zillow, and Figma—are accessible now in supported markets (English), with more partners and developer app submissions opening later this year.

search_results.title: Turn Your ChatGPT Brainstorms Into FigJam Diagrams | Figma Blog
search_results.snippet: Figma announced on Oct 6, 2025 that, starting today, the Figma app in ChatGPT can recommend and create AI‑generated FigJam diagrams from your conversation. It supports text‑based flowcharts, sequence diagrams, state diagrams, and Gantt charts, can be guided by uploaded photos, drawings, or PDFs, and can be invoked with prompts like “Figma, make a diagram…”.

search_results.title: Bring diagrams from ChatGPT to FigJam
search_results.snippet: Figma explains you can generate FigJam diagrams directly in ChatGPT and open them in FigJam to edit and collaborate; this feature is available on any Figma plan but is not yet available in the EU. ChatGPT currently supports diagramming only in FigJam (not Figma Design), with text and basic node shapes embedded inline in ChatGPT, plus pan/zoom, full‑screen, and regenerate options; ChatGPT Free/Plus/Pro users are supported.

What effect did recent pricing and packa.query: What effect did recent pricing and packaging changes have on Figma's Q3 2025 NDR?
What effect did recent pricing and packa.answer: Management said the March 2025 pricing and packaging changes were a growth tailwind and supported expansion. In Q2 FY25, NDR (129% for >$10k ARR customers) was driven by seat expansion plus renewals on the new pricing/packaging, and the CFO flagged a mid- to high-single-digit FY25 tailwind from these changes—implying continued benefit into Q3 FY25 as more customers renewed on the new model.

search_results.title: Updates to our pricing, seats, and billing experience | Figma Blog
search_results.snippet: Figma outlined March 11, 2025 changes: higher Figma Design prices, new multi-product seats (Full, Dev, Collab) with FigJam and Slides included on paid seats, and admin-approved seat upgrades by default—changes that shape expansion and renewals feeding into NDR as customers migrate at renewal.

search_results.title: Figma Announces Second Quarter 2025 Financial Results

How will AI inference costs impact Figma.query: How will AI inference costs impact Figma's gross margin in Q4 2025 and FY2025?
How will AI inference costs impact Figma.answer: Management said higher AI inference costs will drive near‑term gross margin compression, identifying inference spend as the largest driver of q/q margin decline. With Q2 FY2025 non‑GAAP gross margin at ~90% and analysts noting it dipped below 90% as AI investment ramps, margins are expected to remain pressured in Q4 2025. FY2025 guidance contemplates continued AI/product investment and no meaningful AI monetization yet, implying full‑year gross margins below the prior ~90% run‑rate until AI features begin contributing revenue.

search_results.title: Figma (FIG) Q2 2025 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: On the Q2 FY2025 call, CFO Praveer Melwani said non‑GAAP gross margins will compress in the near term as AI usage grows, citing increased inference spend as the largest driver of the quarter‑over‑quarter margin decline; Q2 non‑GAAP gross margin was ~90%. This points to continued margin pressure as AI features roll out, affecting Q4 and the remainder of FY2025.

search_results.title: Figma Analysts Highlight Record Quarter, But Market Focuses On Margins And Growth
search_results.snippet: Analysts noted Figma’s gross margin moved below 90% for the first time as the company continues to invest in AI. RBC said FY25 guidance includes investments in new products/AI but assumes no new product revenue contribution yet, and BofA added the Q3 outlook excludes AI monetization—indicating ongoing margin pressure through FY2025 until AI is monetized.

search_results.title: Figma (FIG) investor relations material — Q2 2025 earnings summary
search_results.snippet: The Q2 FY2025 summary shows 89% GAAP / 90% non‑GAAP gross margin and states management expects continued AI and product investments to impact gross and operating margins in the short term. Guidance: Q3 revenue $263–$265M; FY2025 revenue $1.021–$1.025B and non‑GAAP operating income $88–$98M—implying near‑term margin headwinds as AI costs scale.

Which new AI-powered features will Figma.query: Which new AI-powered features will Figma ship in Q4 2025 and how monetized?
Which new AI-powered features will Figma.answer: In Q4 2025, Figma is shipping two notable AI updates: the Figma app inside ChatGPT that auto-creates FigJam diagrams from conversations and uploads (Oct 6), and Figma Weave—born from its Weavy acquisition—a node-based AI canvas to generate and edit images/video across multiple models (Oct 30). Monetization is via Figma AI credits tied to seat type (e.g., thousands of monthly credits for Full seats), with extra credits slated for purchase later in 2025; publishing and some advanced capabilities (e.g., in Make) remain gated to paid Full seats.

search_results.title: Turn your ChatGPT brainstorms into FigJam diagrams
search_results.snippet: Figma launched a new app inside ChatGPT that can recommend and create FigJam diagrams directly from a conversation, turning chats and uploaded files (sketches, PDFs, photos) into flow charts, sequence and state diagrams, and Gantt charts; it’s live for logged‑in ChatGPT users and describes how teams can invoke it and iterate on outputs.

search_results.title: Figma acquires one-year-old Israeli AI startup Weavy for over $200 million
search_results.snippet: On Oct 30, 2025, Figma acquired Weavy and introduced Figma Weave, a node‑based AI canvas that lets creators mix outputs from multiple AI models and apply pro editing to generate and refine images and video; the company says Weave will be integrated into the Figma platform, expanding its AI media generation and editing capabilities.

search_results.title: Figma’s AI App Building Tool, Figma Make, Now Available For Use
search_results.snippet: Figma detailed monetization via an AI credit system: monthly credits vary by plan/seat (e.g., ~3,000 for Pro Full seats and up to ~4,250 for Enterprise), with publish rights and broader capabilities gated to paid Full seats; Figma also confirms plans to let admins buy additional AI credits later in 2025.

What acquisitions is Figma actively eval.query: What acquisitions is Figma actively evaluating after Modyfi and Payload to enhance developer workflows?
What acquisitions is Figma actively eval.answer: Figma has not named any new acquisition targets beyond Modyfi and Payload. In its IPO materials and recent remarks, leadership said they will keep pursuing M&A at scale—especially around AI and developer workflows—to deepen design‑to‑code and Dev Mode capabilities. In other words, Figma is actively evaluating additional developer‑tooling and AI deals, but no specific post‑Modyfi/Payload acquisitions have been disclosed.

search_results.title: Figma's IPO: Design is everyone's business

search_results.title: Figma (FIG) Q2 2025 Earnings Call Transcript
search_results.snippet: On the Q2 2025 call, Figma highlighted new Dev Mode MCP integrations to speed developer workflows and confirmed the acquisitions of Modyfi (visual expression) and Payload (open‑source CMS/app framework). Which LLM providers power Figma's AI fea.query: Which LLM providers power Figma's AI features in 2025 and what are unit costs?
Which LLM providers power Figma's AI fea.answer: In 2025, Figma confirms it uses third‑party models to power AI features, including Anthropic’s Claude (rolled out as Claude Sonnet 4.5 in Figma Make) and Google’s Gemini models (Gemini 2.5 Flash, Gemini 2.0) plus Imagen 4 for image generation. Figma doesn’t publish per‑unit dollar pricing; instead, usage is metered via AI credits included with seats: Full seats get 3,000 (Professional), 3,500 (Organization), or 4,250 (Enterprise) credits per month—roughly 50–100 Make prompts. Figma says admins will be able to buy additional AI credits later in 2025, but per‑credit pricing hasn’t been disclosed.

search_results.title: How AI credits work – Figma Learn - Help Center
search_results.snippet: Figma meters AI usage with credits shared across features. Full seats include monthly credits—3,000 (Professional), 3,500 (Organization), and 4,250 (Enterprise)—which Figma estimates translate to roughly 50–100 Figma Make prompts. Credits reset (unused credits don’t roll over). Figma plans to let admins purchase additional AI credits later in 2025; per‑credit pricing is not published.

search_results.title: Figma partners with Google to add Gemini AI to its design platform
search_results.snippet: In Oct 2025, Figma integrated Google’s AI stack—Gemini 2.5 Flash, Gemini 2.0, and Imagen 4—into its platform for image editing and generation, with tests showing a 50% latency reduction on the “Make Image” feature. The partnership is non‑exclusive, indicating Figma uses multiple model providers.

search_results.title: Figma Live: Figma x Anthropic on Claude Sonnet 4.5
search_results.snippet: Figma’s official live stream (Sept 29, 2025) announces, “Starting today, we’re rolling out Claude Sonnet 4.5 in Figma Make,” confirming Anthropic’s Claude powers Figma Make. Figma’s team and an Anthropic engineer discuss model evaluation, deployment, and how the Claude model enhances Make.

How will Figma ensure compliance with th.query: How will Figma ensure compliance with the EU AI Act for generative features in 2025?
How will Figma ensure compliance with th.answer: In 2025, Figma states it will align its generative features with the EU AI Act through strong data‑governance and transparency controls while relying on compliant third‑party general‑purpose AI (GPAI) providers. Figma’s approach prevents model vendors from training on customer content, limits retention, de‑identifies/redacts data, and gives admins an opt‑in/opt‑out “Content Training” toggle (default off for Organization/Enterprise), alongside clear AI‑output disclosures in its AI Terms. As GPAI obligations took effect in August 2025, primary duties such as training‑data transparency and copyright compliance sit with model providers, while Figma, as an AI system provider, must meet user‑information and transparency expectations and align with EU Commission guidance and tools.

search_results.title: Building Figma AI
search_results.snippet: Figma explains that its generative features use third‑party models; it bars those providers from training on customer content, limits vendor data retention, de‑identifies/redacts data, and provides admin controls to opt in/out of “Content Training” (default off for Organization/Enterprise). It also notes Figma AI became generally available on July 24, 2025—measures that support EU‑style data governance and transparency.

search_results.title: Figma AI Terms
search_results.snippet: Effective May 2, 2025, Figma’s AI Terms set controls over Input/Output ownership, a “Content Training” toggle to govern whether customer content may be used to improve models, and clear AI‑output limitations requiring human review. The terms tie AI use to the Acceptable Use Policy and can be updated—disclosing responsibilities and safeguards consistent with EU AI Act transparency expectations.

search_results.title: AI Act | Shaping Europe's digital future - European Union
search_results.snippet: The EU AI Act applies risk‑based rules and, from August 2, 2025, obligations for GPAI model providers take effect (transparency and copyright). The Commission issued GPAI guidance, a voluntary Code of Practice, and a template for public training‑data summaries, and requires that generative AI outputs be identifiable (with deepfakes labeled)—tools and duties Figma’s upstream model providers and downstream system providers must align with.

What data residency options does Figma o.query: What data residency options does Figma offer EU enterprise customers as of Q3 2025?
What data residency options does Figma o.answer: As of Q3 2025, Figma offers an EU data residency option for Enterprise organizations: admins can enable EU data hosting so the contents of Figma files (Design, FigJam, Slides, Draw, Buzz, Make) are stored at rest on AWS in the EU, with primary storage in Frankfurt and backups in Dublin. Non-file data (e.g., comments, file names, billing, metadata, logs, search index, Community assets, user profiles) and published or in-transit data are not localized and may be processed in the U.S.; migrations can be requested via the Admin settings.

search_results.title: Enable localized file hosting in the EU – Figma Learn - Help Center
search_results.snippet: Figma’s Data Residency Solution, available only on the Enterprise plan, lets org admins host key parts of Figma content at rest in the EU on AWS. Localizable data includes shapes, text boxes (minus @mentions), sticky notes, frames, components, images and videos across Figma Design, FigJam, Slides, Draw, Buzz and Make; comments, file names, fonts, thumbnails and Dev Mode/Code Connect inspect code are not localized. Non‑file data (billing, metadata, activity/security logs, search index, Community assets, user profiles, etc.) is out of scope and remains hosted/processed in the U.S.; published content is excluded; migrations are requested via Admin > Settings > Data storage localization.

search_results.title: EU hosting for Figma and FigJam files | Figma Blog
search_results.snippet: Figma offers EU file data hosting for Enterprise customers, with primary storage in Frankfurt (Germany) and backup in Dublin (Ireland), using AWS. The option localizes document contents of Figma and FigJam (see Help Center for supported types), while user metadata/login and some in‑transit data are not hosted in the EU.

search_results.title: Figma Enterprise
search_results.snippet: The Enterprise plan includes compliance controls that allow organizations to turn on EU data hosting, alongside network access and session policies. What is Figma's pricing localization str.query: What is Figma's pricing localization strategy for India, Brazil, and Japan in 2025?

What cost optimization initiatives is Fi.query: What cost optimization initiatives is Figma pursuing in 2025 to protect operating margins?

What major technical debt reduction init.query: What major technical debt reduction initiatives is Figma executing in 2025 to improve velocity?
What major technical debt reduction init.answer: In 2025, Figma is paying down core technical debt to boost development and product velocity in three big ways: unifying its duplicative parameter systems (variables and component properties) under a single data model/runtime to eliminate inconsistencies and speed engineering; modernizing its rendering engine to WebGPU with a new graphics interface and shader tooling to unlock performance headroom and reduce WebGL’s maintenance pitfalls; and optimizing Rust data structures in its multiplayer/file decoding path, cutting p99 deserialization by ~20% and memory costs by ~20% to keep file loads fast at scale.

search_results.title: A tale of two parameter architectures—and how we unified them
search_results.snippet: Figma explains that shipping variables and component properties separately left them with two divergent parameter architectures that caused inconsistent behavior and complexity. In 2025 they unified the data model and runtime powering both, enabling cross‑system bindings, removing duplicated type systems, and—critically—“eliminated user-facing inconsistencies, improved developer velocity, and created a scalable foundation” for future features.

search_results.title: Figma rendering: Powered by WebGPU
search_results.snippet: In Sept 2025, Figma upgraded its renderer to WebGPU, redesigning the graphics interface (explicit draw-call arguments, batched uniform buffers) and adding an automated GLSL→WGSL shader pipeline while keeping WebGL compatibility. The move avoids WebGL’s fragile global state and enables compute‑driven GPU optimizations—reducing long‑term maintenance overhead and expanding performance headroom.

search_results.title: Supporting faster file load times with memory optimizations in Rust
search_results.snippet: June 2025: Figma reworked Rust data structures in a critical multiplayer/file decoding path (replacing a BTreeMap with a compact sorted vector, exploring bit‑stuffing) to reduce memory and speed up deserialization. Results: ~20% faster file deserialization at the 99th percentile and ~20% lower memory costs across the multiplayer fleet—keeping file loads fast as server‑side decode volume grew.

How is Figma countering Adobe Creative C.query: How is Figma countering Adobe Creative Cloud bundling in enterprise RFPs during 2025?
How is Figma countering Adobe Creative C.answer: In 2025, Figma is countering Adobe’s Creative Cloud bundling in enterprise RFPs by expanding into a broader, single-vendor suite and by shifting to role-based, multi-product licensing. At Config 2025 it launched Sites, Draw, Buzz, and Make to keep marketing, web publishing, illustration, AI prototyping, and design-to-dev handoff in one platform. It also restructured pricing into Full, Dev, and Collab seats that bundle multiple products per user and added admin approval and prorated billing to control spend. To meet RFP security and compliance requirements, Figma’s Enterprise plan adds SSO/SCIM, EU data hosting, Governance+ (IP allowlists, network restrictions, enforced 2FA), and granular sharing/monitoring—helping enterprises avoid all-apps bundling while checking procurement boxes.

search_results.title: Updates to Figma’s pricing, seats, and billing experience
search_results.snippet: Effective March 11, 2025, Figma moved to multi‑product, role‑based seats—Full, Dev, and Collab—so each user’s seat includes access to multiple products (e.g., FigJam and Slides by default), with admins gaining upfront approval controls and prorated billing for upgrades. This packaging bundles Figma tools while giving enterprises fine‑grained cost governance, a procurement‑friendly alternative to all‑apps bundling in RFPs.

search_results.title: Config 2025 launches deepen Figma’s design capabilities as its platform expands
search_results.snippet: At Config 2025, Figma doubled its product offering with Sites (web publishing), Draw (vector illustration), Buzz (brand/marketing content), Make (AI prompt‑to‑code), plus Grid and enhanced AI—positioning an integrated, idea‑to‑production workflow. What data sources does Figma use to trai.query: What data sources does Figma use to train or fine-tune AI features in 2025?
What data sources does Figma use to trai.answer: In 2025, Figma trains its models using two main categories: optional customer content (e.g., text, images, comments, annotations, layer names/properties) when admins enable the “Content training” setting, and aggregated, de‑identified usage data (e.g., access counts, logs, metadata, telemetry). Separately, select features like Visual Search, Asset Search, and Add Interactions are fine‑tuned on data from public, free Figma Community files. Figma excludes Education and Government accounts from training, and says third‑party providers (e.g., OpenAI) are not permitted to train their own models on Figma customer data.

search_results.title: Building Figma AI
search_results.snippet: Figma outlines its training sources as: optional customer content (text, images, comments/annotations, layer names/properties) and aggregated, de‑identified usage data (access frequency, technical logs, metadata, telemetry). It also notes that select features (Visual Search, Asset Search, Add Interactions) are fine‑tuned on public, free Community files, while generative features rely on third‑party, out‑of‑the‑box models. report:
# FIGMA, INC. (NYSE: FIG) — Equity Research Report

## 1) Investment Recommendation Summary
- Stance: NEUTRAL
- Rating: HOLD
- Next market day outlook (Nov 6, 2025): Expect elevated volatility with a negative bias as investors digest Q3 prints/guidance against AI-driven gross margin compression and a sizable lock-up release on Nov 7; baseline scenario is modest downside absent a material “beat and raise” and/or clearer AI monetization timing [4][5][6][11][12][13][10].

## 2) Executive Summary
Figma remains a category leader in collaborative design with strong revenue visibility, robust expansion within the enterprise, and rising multi-product adoption. FY2025 revenue guidance of $1.021–$1.025B (midpoint ~37% y/y) and Q3 revenue guidance of $263–$265M (~33% y/y) underscore durable top-line momentum [4][5][6]. Net dollar retention for >$10k ARR customers is 129%, driven by seat expansion and renewals under the new pricing/packaging model, which management expects to be a mid- to high-single-digit tailwind in FY2025 [9]. However, near-term profitability is pressured: AI inference costs pushed gross margin below 90% and are expected to keep compressing margins until monetization scales [11][12][13].

Liquidity is strong (cash and investments of $1.6B and an undrawn $500M revolver), but Figma has a material five-year AWS minimum spend commitment ($545M) and significant equity overhang from RSUs and the impending lock-up release (~38.9M shares on Nov 7, with further staged releases) [16][1][2][3][7][8][20][10]. Given the event path (results/guidance today and lock-up on Friday), we recommend HOLD into the volatility and await post-lock-up clarity on price discovery, AI monetization cadence, and margin trajectory.

## 3) Company Overview
Figma provides a browser-native, collaborative platform spanning product design (Figma Design), ideation (FigJam), developer workflows (Dev Mode), presentations (Slides), and AI-enhanced tools (Make, Draw, Sites, Buzz). The company relies on Amazon Web Services for production services and entered a renewed hosting agreement on May 31, 2025 with a five-year minimum commitment of ~$545M [7][8]. Figma bills predominantly on annual terms, supporting revenue visibility [18].

## 4) Key Findings by Category

### Revenue and Growth
- FY2025 revenue guidance: $1.021–$1.025B; midpoint implies ~37% y/y growth [4][5][6].
- Q3 revenue guidance: $263–$265M; midpoint ~33% y/y [4][5][6].
- Q2 revenue: $249.6M (+41% y/y) [5].
- Expansion metrics:
  - NDR (customers >$10k ARR): 129%, driven by seat expansion and renewals on new pricing/packaging; management cited a mid- to high-single-digit FY2025 growth tailwind from these changes [9].
  - Multi-product usage: >80% using 2+ products; ~two-thirds using 3+ [16].
  - Customers >$100k ARR: 1,119 as of Q2 (June 30, 2025) [5].
- Revenue visibility: ~70% of Q2 revenue recognized came from beginning-of-period deferred revenue, consistent with annual billings [18].

Analyst view: Growth durability is supported by enterprise penetration, multiproduct adoption, and pricing/packaging tailwinds. The absence of pipeline coverage disclosure limits visibility into late-stage conversion into Q4 [5].

### Profitability and Margins
- Q2 gross margin: ~89% GAAP / ~90% non-GAAP; management signaled a further near-term decline on AI inference usage and investment [11][12][13].
- FY2025 non-GAAP operating income guidance: $88–$98M, reflecting near-term margin headwinds as AI costs scale ahead of monetization [12][13].
- Free cash flow: Q2 adjusted FCF margin ~24%; management commentary and external estimates support low-20s FY2025 FCF conversion (~$216M on ~$1.023B revenue) [9][17].

Analyst view: AI cost-to-serve is the key margin swing factor. Without near-term monetization uplift, we expect continued gross margin compression in Q4 and into FY2025, with opex discipline offsetting some pressure [11][12][13][9].

### Cash, Liquidity, and Commitments
- Cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities: ~$1.6B as of June 30, 2025 [16].
- Revolving credit facility: $500M senior secured revolver (undrawn), maturing June 27, 2030; SOFR/base-rate with applicable margin; unused commitment fee; standard L/C and swingline sublimits [1][2][3].
- Hosting commitments: AWS minimum of ~$545M over five years from May 31, 2025 [7][8].
- Leases: Remaining 2025 $8.5M; 2026 $14.0M; 2027 $14.0M; 2028 $13.6M; 2029 $8.0M; thereafter $30.2M; PV of operating lease liabilities $64.7M; SF HQ lease extended to Oct 31, 2028 [1][19].

Analyst view: Liquidity is ample, but multi-year cloud commitments and AI inference spend reduce flexibility. The undrawn revolver and strong cash buffer mitigate near-term risk [1][2][3][7][8][16].

### Product, Pricing, and AI
- March 11, 2025 pricing update: higher Figma Design prices, FigJam/Slides included with paid seats, multi-product seats, admin controls; applied at customer renewal from March 11 onward [14].
- AI credits: monthly pooled credits per full seat (3,000 Pro; 3,500 Org; 4,250 Enterprise), roughly 50–100 Make prompts; no per-credit pricing published; paid top-ups planned in 2025 [15].
- New products/AI: Make, Draw, Sites, Buzz launched in Q2 [5].
- Dev Mode enterprise adoption: not disclosed [9].
- Product attach rates by SKU: not disclosed (aggregate multi-product usage reported) [16].

Analyst view: Packaging changes are driving ARPU uplift and adoption breadth. AI monetization is early; lack of published unit pricing and per-product attach metrics obscures near-term revenue uplift vs. cost-to-serve [14][15][16][9].

### Go-to-Market and Cost Efficiency
- Sales and marketing intensity fell to ~39% of revenue in Q2 from ~46% y/y despite Config spend; no explicit H2 marketing % guidance [9][1][4].
- Cost optimization: migration from ECS to Kubernetes (EKS) with autoscaling (Karpenter/KEDA) to curb over-provisioning and reduce cloud costs [24][25].
- Enterprise pipeline coverage: not disclosed [5].
- Hiring: NYC expansion to add 242 high-wage roles, majority in R&D [27].

Analyst view: GTM efficiency is improving; engineering-led cloud cost optimization partially offsets AI inference headwinds [24][25][9].

### Capital Structure, Supply, and Overhang
- Lock-up: Standard IPO lock-ups end at the open on the second trading day after Q3 earnings—Nov 7, 2025. Extended Lock-Up covers ~54.1% of Class A; 17.5% of that pool (~38.9M shares) releases on Nov 7, with later staged releases (~44.4M, ~61.1M, ~77.7M) [10].
- RSU overhang: registration covers 201,327,898 Class A shares for equity plans and 40,210,338 Class B shares under the 2021 Executive Plan for RSU settlement [20].
- Insider plan: CEO Dylan Field’s 10b5-1 plan may sell up to 3,067,662 shares Nov 24, 2025–Nov 30, 2026 subject to price triggers (thresholds undisclosed) [10].

Analyst view: Near-term float expansion (Nov 7) and sizeable equity overhang are meaningful technical headwinds for the stock near and just after results [10][20].

### Taxes and Capex
- Non-GAAP tax rate: company uses a long-term projected rate of 25% for adjustments; subject to change with laws and geographic mix of earnings [26][4][5].
- Capex: modest ($2.0M in 1H25); external forecasts imply ~$17.4M in 2026, consistent with opex-heavy cloud/AI spend [3][22].

## 5) Investment Thesis

### Bull Case
- Durable growth and expansion:
  - FY2025 revenue growth guided ~37% at midpoint; Q3 guidance ~33% y/y [4][5][6].
  - 129% NDR for >$10k ARR cohort with seat expansion and renewal uplift from new packaging [9].
  - Broad product adoption (>80% using 2+ products; two-thirds using 3+) and annual billing model support visibility [16][18].
- Strong balance sheet and liquidity:
  - ~$1.6B cash and investments plus an undrawn $500M revolver [16][1][2][3].
- Product and platform leverage:
  - Pricing/packaging changes are a mid- to high-single-digit tailwind in FY2025; AI products launched expand TAM [9][5].
  - Engineering initiatives (EKS + autoscaling) drive cloud cost efficiency gains [24][25].

### Bear Case
- Margin compression and AI monetization risk:
  - Gross margin dipped below 90% and management expects continued pressure from inference costs absent near-term monetization; guidance and analyst commentary indicate AI investments not yet meaningfully monetized [11][12][13].
- Technical and dilution overhang:
  - Nov 7 lock-up release (~38.9M shares) and subsequent tranches increase float materially; large RSU pool adds ongoing dilution risk [10][20].
- Visibility gaps:
  - No disclosed pipeline coverage ratio; limited per-product attach detail; Dev Mode enterprise KPIs not reported [5][16][9].
- Vendor concentration and fixed commitments:
  - Heavy reliance on AWS with a five-year $545M minimum commitment reduces flexibility if workloads or pricing shift unfavorably [7][8].

## 6) Key Risks
- AI cost-to-serve outpacing monetization could further compress gross margins in Q4/FY2025 [11][12][13].
- Share supply pressure from lock-up releases and RSU settlements could weigh on valuation and increase volatility [10][20].
- Execution risk on packaging changes and AI feature adoption; lack of granular attach/usage metrics increases uncertainty [14][15][16][9].
- Cloud concentration and multi-year hosting commitments limit cost flexibility amid volatile AI workloads [7][8].
- Limited disclosure on sales pipeline coverage and GRR hinders forecasting precision [5][23].

## 7) Conclusion and Outlook
- Rating: HOLD (NEUTRAL stance)
- Near-term outlook (next market day, Nov 6, 2025): We expect heightened volatility, with a negative bias as investors weigh Q3 results/guidance against continued gross margin compression from AI inference and the imminent Nov 7 lock-up release (~38.9M shares) [11][12][13][10]. Baseline scenario: modest downside unless the print delivers a clear “beat and raise” with improved AI monetization visibility.
- What to watch today:
  - FY2025 guidance trajectory vs. prior $1.021–$1.025B range and Q3 revenue cadence [4][5][6].
  - Gross margin trend and commentary on AI cost mitigation and monetization timing [11][12][13][24][25][15].
  - Expansion metrics: NDR durability, >$100k customer growth, and breadth of multi-product adoption [9][5][16].
  - Cash/investment balance, cloud commitments cadence, and any revolver utilization updates [16][7][8][1][2].

We would look to upgrade on: 1) clear AI monetization (pricing for credits/usage and attach evidence), 2) stabilization/improvement in gross margins, 3) post-lock-up price discovery and liquidity normalization, and 4) improved disclosure on enterprise pipeline/attach to increase forecast confidence [15][11][12][13][10][5][16].
